text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This transmits revised IRM 4.71.16, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, Employee Plans Large Case Examinations, and lists supplemental information for procedures speciﬁc to Large Case examinations.
BACKGROUND
IRM 4.71.16 provides guidance and information to help EP examiners working Employee Plans (EP) Large Case Support Examination cases.
Large Case Support Examination cases. (
) This IRM is intended to provide supplemental information for procedures speciﬁc to EP Large Case Support Examinations and it is not intended to replace IRM
, Overview of Form
Examination Procedures or IRM
, Employee Plans Large Case Support Examination Procedure. (
) Examiners should follow these procedures when doing a Large Case examination (a plan with
participants or more). (
) General program examiners should refer to the following processes and procedures: • as an examination tool for examining retirement plans with
or more participants

MATERIAL CHANGES

Modiﬁed IRM 4.71.16.1.2 (3) to update the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) content based on guidance from the Division Counsel/Associate Chief Counsel (National Taxpayer Advocate Program) and Branch 3 of the Associate Chief Counsel. (Procedure and Administration).
Modiﬁed IRM 4.71.16.1.6 to provide additional guidance for safeguarding personally identiﬁable

Renamed and revised IRM 4.71.16.1.7, Contact Information, to reference the new location for Important contact information for individuals and business units which is now found in IRM 4.71.1 - Exhibit 13 , Contact Information.

Revised IRM 4.71.16.1.8, Case Suspense for Federally Declared Disaster, or Terrorist or Military Action, to reference the procedures in 4.71.1.1.10, Case Suspense for Federally Declared Disaster, or Terrorist or Military Action, and the subsections thereunder. IRM 4.71.16.1.8.1, Mandatory Suspension of Activities During the Postponement Period, and 4.71.16.8.2, Statute of Limitations Expiring During the Postponement Period, were deleted since these procedures are found in IRM 4.71.1.1.10.1, Mandatory Suspension of Activities, and IRM 4.71.1.1.10.2, Statute of Limitations Expiring During the Postponement Period,

Revised IRM 4.71.16.8.1 to incorporate the provisions of the February 2, 2021, IGM TEGE-04-0221- 0003 with the subject line, Interim Guidance on Letter Consolidation, from the Acting Deputy Commissioner, TEGE, which require the use of Letter 6031, TE/GE Opening Examination Letter.

throughout replacing the terms “agent” and “agents” with “examiner” and “examiners”, and replacing the terms “audit”, “auditing” and “audited” with “examination”, “examining”, and “examined”. Generally, official titles and designations do not reﬂect this change. Editorial changes were made throughout this IRM for: • Grammar

Revised IRM 4.71.16.10.3(6) to reﬂect new required use of Form 5773-A speciﬁed in the December 14, 2020, IGM TEGE-04-1220-0026 with the subject line, Requirement to use Form 5773-A (Rev. 12-2020), and eliminating required use of Form 5772-A, from the Director, EP Examinations.

Revised IRM 4.71.16 throughout replacing the terms “agent” and “agents” with “examiner” and “examiners”, and replacing the terms “audit”, “auditing” and “audited” with “examination”, “examining”, and “examined”. Generally, official titles and designations do not reﬂect this change.
Editorial changes were made throughout this IRM for:

Updating organizational terms, titles, and acronyms. Updating or correcting references and citations, added links to references. Updating for broken links. Reorganized IRM without changing any substantive content in its meaning. Other changes for Plan Language (the Plain Writing Act of
) and conformity
, IRM Style Guide revised
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This supersedes IRM 4.71.16 dated October 30, 2019.

Cite Speciﬁc authority IRC Section 7602 - Examination of books and witnesses, which falls under Chapter 78 - Discovery of Liability and En- forcement of Title • Audit any books, papers, records or other data necessary to complete an audit. • Take testimony under oath to secure additional infor- mation needed. • Issue summons for infor- mation necessary to complete an audit. • Ask about any offense connected to the adminis- tering or enforcing of the Internal Revenue laws. IRC Section 6201- Assessment authority, which falls under Chapter 63 - Assessment. Resolve issues based on authority to make determinations of tax liability under IRC 6201.
This IRM section is authored by EP Mandatory Review. For questions, informa- tion or suggestions, contact the manager of EP Mandatory Review.
EP Examinations determines if a retirement plan is qualiﬁed under IRC 401 and the underlying regulations, and therefore, exempt from tax under IRC 501.

a. Promote the highest degree of voluntary compliance with the tax laws governing plan qualiﬁcation. b. Determine the extent of compliance and the causes of noncompliance with the tax laws. c. Determine whether such plans meet the applicable qualiﬁcation require
ments in operation.
EP examiners and managers are given broad authority to:
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

a. Consider and weigh conﬂicting information, data, and opinions. b. To use professional judgement per auditing standards to ﬁnd facts and apply the IRS’s position on issues of law to determine the correct tax liability. c. To exercise this authority to obtain the greatest number of tax determina- tion agreements without sacriﬁcing the quality or integrity of those determinations and to dispose of tax differences at the lowest level. See IRM
, Policy Statement
, Examination authority to resolve issues. (
) Examinations must be conducted with integrity and fairness. See IRM
, Policy Statement
, Fairness and Integrity in Enforcement Selection. Controls (
) Two review groups make sure examiners conduct examinations per technical, procedural and administrative requirements: a. Mandatory Review, see IRM
, Employee Plans Examination of Returns, EP Mandatory Review. b. Special Review, see IRM
, Special Review (SR) and Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) Procedures. (
) Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) is the quality control system TE/GE uses to oversee the entire examination program. For more in- formation on TEQMS, see IRM
, Special Review (SR) and Tax Exempt Quality Measurement System (TEQMS) Procedures. (
) The Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) lists rights that already existed in the tax code, putting them in simple language and grouping them into
fundamental rights. Employees are responsible for being familiar with and acting in accord with taxpayer rights. See IRC
), Execution of Duties in Accord with Taxpayer Rights. For additional information about the TBOR, see https://www. irs.gov/taxpayer-bill-of-rights . (
) The IRS is fully committed to protecting the privacy rights of taxpayers and employees. Privacy laws are included in the IRC, the Privacy Act of

, Freedom of Information Act, and IRS policies and practices. For more informa- tion about these laws, visit the IRS Electronic Freedom of Information Act Reading Room . a. For questions about privacy, email *Privacy . b. For question about disclosure, email *Disclosure . (

This manual uses the following terms. See their deﬁnitions below.

Term Deﬁnition Case identiﬁcation specialist (CIS) EP employee who identiﬁes the Large Case exam universe. Large Case team (team) An examination team made up of: • The Large Case manager • The Large Case team co- ordinator • EP examiner(s) • Other Large Case team members as needed: CAS, the area actuary, EP Counsel, and other examiners directed byf the Large Case manager Large Case audit plan a written document containing the examination scope, distribution of work assignments, examination procedures, time estimates, and special instructions.
A meeting(s) with the Large Case manager and team to discuss the scope of the examination and to review the case. At the meeting’s conclusion, the Large Case manager and the team coordina
tor determine areas to include in the Large Case audit plan. The LB&I coordinator, EO TEP Coor
dinator, Support Specialist manager(s), etc. may also be invited to these meetings at the manager’s discretion.
Employee Plans Large Case Examinations

Term Deﬁnition Pre-contact analysis A study of available information to set the exam’s initial scope and depth. This includes discussions with the taxpayer to get or clarify return information. Use informa- tion you gain at the opening conference to supplement your pre-contact analysis. This helps construct the Large Case audit plan. Risk analysis A process which evaluates the potential beneﬁt derived from examining an issue or a return, compared to the cost of resources required to perform the examination. The plan’s internal control systems and processes’ accuracy and reliability are important items to consider when you complete a risk analysis. Status meetings Scheduled meetings with the taxpayer to discuss case progress, items pending and time-line for completion. Support specialists Actuaries, commodity and ﬁnancial products examiners, engineers, excise tax examiners, economists, international examiners, CAS, Exempt Organi- zations examiners, Tax-Exempt Bonds examiners, Indian Tribal Government specialists, and any other specialist necessary. Use the automated Specialist Referral System (SRS) to request their help. Support specialist’s manager Participates in managing the spe- cialists’ activities, but the Large Case manager has primary re- sponsibility for the examination. Participates in managing the spe
cialists’ activities, but the Large Case manager has primary re
sponsibility for the examination.
Term Deﬁnition Taxpayer A business, person or trust asso- ciated with qualiﬁed retirement plans, including: MAP, IRC
(b) and IRC
plans. The three potential taxpayers in a Large Case examination are: the spon- soring employer, the trust, and the plan participants/ beneﬁciaries. of Large Case (
) Large Case examinations involve the largest qualiﬁed retirement plans. a. Most of the plans selected as a Large Case exam have at least
participants. b. Occasionally, managers assign a plan with less than
participants when the smaller plan is associated with a LB&I taxpayer or for training purposes. (

) Large Case examiners: a. Generally, conduct focused examinations of large and complex employee plans. b. Evaluate and analyze the plan sponsor’s internal controls, systems processes to help them identify the examination areas, such as participation, coverage, vesting, assets, distributions, accruals, forfeitures, and other compliance issues. c. Always verify that the plan is qualiﬁed in form for all years under exami- nation. Review the plan document and all amendments in effect for year(s) under examination. (

) Large Case procedures and guidelines: a. Promote uniformity and consistency in administering Large Case nations. b. Help the Large Case manager (manager) and Large Case Team nator (coordinator) with their examination responsibilities. c. Help orient prospective Large Case team members to Large Case nation concepts and techniques. (
) Unless otherwise stated, the procedures for general program examinations apply to Large Case examinations. Personally Information (

) IRS employees are required to ensure that sensitive information is protected from unauthorized disclosure and access. This requirement not only includes return information but also includes other non-tax information, documents, records and processes. (
) When possible, mask the ﬁrst ﬁve digits of a taxpayer’s SSN on letters, notices, workpapers and emails. Example: XXX-XX-
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

Term Deﬁnition Taxpayer A business, person or trust asso- ciated with qualiﬁed retirement plans, including: MAP, IRC 403(b) and IRC 457 plans. The three potential taxpayers in a Large Case examination are: the spon- soring employer, the trust, and the plan participants/ beneﬁciaries. 4.71 Employee Plans Examination of Returns
a. Most of the plans selected as a Large Case exam have at least
participants. b. Occasionally, managers assign a plan with less than
participants when the smaller plan is associated with a LB&I taxpayer or for training purposes.

Generally, conduct focused examinations of large and complex employee plans. Evaluate and analyze the plan sponsor’s internal controls, systems and processes to help them identify the examination areas, such as eligibility, participation, coverage, vesting, assets, distributions, accruals, forfeitures, and other compliance issues. Always verify that the plan is qualiﬁed in form for all years under exami
nation. Review the plan document and all amendments in effect for the year(s) under examination.
When possible, mask the ﬁrst ﬁve digits of a taxpayer’s SSN on letters, forms, notices, workpapers and emails.

Important contact information for individuals and business units referenced in this IRM are listed in IRM 4.71.1 - Exhibit 13 , Contact Information.
The Large Case manager contacts the responsible LB&I, EO, or Fed State Local/ET manager when they assign a case to a Large Case examiner.
4.71 Employee Plans Examination of Returns
of the Manager (

) The Large Case manager is responsible for all assigned Large Case members’ activities and must be personally involved in the exam’s progress. The manager’s primary responsibilities are: a. Coordinating and planning the examination with the LB&I, Fed State Local/ET, or EO team manager, if necessary b. Coordinating with Area Counsel and the EP actuary, if necessary c. Consulting with the Large Case Team coordinator to determine plans and plan years to examine Note: These decisions depend on program objectives, examiner availabil- ity, and taxpayer resources. d. Conducting examination visits, as necessary, while the Large Case ex- amination is in progress e. Following and approving the Large Case engagement agreement (if prepared), the Large Case audit plan, and all substantial changes to the audit plan and examination procedures f. Ensuring that each team member disclosed all ﬁnancial and conﬂict of interest issues g. Discussing continuously with the Large Case team coordinator and team members to determine the examination’s progress h. Consulting with the Large Case Team coordinator when problems develop such as delays in responses to IDRs i. Participating in taxpayer meetings j. Reviewing each team member’s workpapers and reports during and at end of the examination process k. Ensuring that the Large Case team coordinator has obtained appropriate written contact authorization from the taxpayer l. Approving expansion or contraction of issues in the Large Case audit plan including expanding to other years and related returns m. Reviewing and approving Notices of Proposed Adjustments n. Approving Employee Plans Compliance Resolution System (EPCRS) checksheets (CAP & SCP) o. Reviewing and approving the closing letter(s) (
) The manager must monitor the Large Case examination progress. (
) The primary monitoring techniques are visits and meetings with Large Case

) The manager must monitor the Large Case examination progress. (
) The primary monitoring techniques are visits and meetings with Large Case Team members and the taxpayer. (

) The Large Case Manager should plan visits, whether on-site or at any other location, with the following objectives in mind: a. Determine that communications are open b. Evaluate the effectiveness of the Large Case engagement agreement prepared) and the Large Case audit plan and make necessary adjust- ments when appropriate c. Check on progress d. Identify problems e. Provide instructions for corrective action f. Evaluate personnel g. Help resolve issues (
) The manager should keep a case ﬁle with the information necessary to stay informed of the case status. Examples of items that may be included in the are:
(5) The manager should keep a case ﬁle with the information necessary to stay informed of the case status. Examples of items that may be included in the ﬁle

a. Large Case engagement agreement (if prepared) b. Form
(Large Case) and updates. See IRM
- Exhibit
, Sample EPTA Audit Plan. c. List of support specialists involved in the examination d. Minutes from status meetings, and e. Status report of the examination (
) The manager is encouraged to maintain any other data that is useful in managing the case. (

) The manager should consider a risk analysis at various intervals during the examination to assess the viability of issues and appropriateness of the resources used. Note: The manager and coordinator determine the format and timing of the risk analysis. (
) The Large Case Manager will regularly communicate with the Large Case Team Coordinator to monitor the progress of the examination. (
) On-site visits and meetings are important elements of the manager’s involve- ment in the case. The manager shouldn’t delegate this responsibility to others. (

) During a visit, the manager may: a. Determine whether the team is working examination issues in priority order and whether changes to the audit plan exam scope and depth are appropriate and timely b. Review progress on action items generated during previous reviews c. Review examination issues in process and discuss with the coordinator the need to expand, contract, or redirect examination activity d. Review examination issues not in process and determine what, if any, impact subsequent events have had on their potential for adjustment e. Review Form
-A for completeness and accuracy prior to issuing f. Review Form
-B and other completed workpapers to ensure that examination trail is well documented and issues are being properly developed g. Review IDR log and IDR turnaround time (

) There are several types of visits, depending on the stage of examination. These include: a. Planning visits to develop the Large Case engagement agreement (if prepared) and the Large Case audit plan b. Monitoring visits with team members and the taxpayer while the examina- tion is underway c. Status meetings d. Problem-solving visits with team members and the taxpayer e. Visits with team members to develop a uniform presentation of proposed issues to the taxpayer (

) During a visit to an examination site, the manager may need to meet with the appropriate levels of company management to discuss the progress of the amination and to resolve any potential problems. (

Employee Plans Examination of Returns
(1) The coordinator is the ﬁrst Large Case team member the manager selects.

The coordinator is the ﬁrst Large Case team member the manager selects. During the examination, the coordinator is the focal point for communication with the team members. The Large Case Team coordinator’s primary responsibilities are: a. Preparing the Large Case audit plan and the optional Large Case en- gagement agreement b. Obtaining proper disclosure written authorization and Form

signed by the taxpayer’s authorized official c. Coordinating the exam’s day-to-day activities d. Protecting the statute of limitations e. Coordinating the assignments, receipt of information and team members’ (including specialists assigned to the plan examination) progress f. Coordinating the correspondence between the team members and the taxpayer (help team members and specialists to follow up on IDRs and timely involve all levels of management, if necessary) g. Serving as the point of contact for the prompt and orderly ﬂow of informa- tion h. Coordinating with the CAS to make sure the team receives records on time to conduct the examination, including record retention agreements, necessary i. Reviewing Form
-B proposed by team members j. Approving Form
-A before the manager approves Note: See IRM
- Exhibit
, Form

-A. k. Advising team members including LB&I, EO, or Fed State Local/ET of de- veloping issues l. Preparing a write-up of the history of the company, owners and plans m. Coordinating our review of the internal controls and preparing an analysis identifying the strengths and weaknesses in the systems and processes consider when preparing the audit plan n. Advising and helping team members to comply and understand agree- ments made at the opening conference o. Timely informing the manager of any problems between the taxpayer and team members or problems among team members p. Receiving and reviewing team members’ IDRs to ensure uniformity, clarity, and avoidance of duplication, (this includes coordinating IDRs issuance with the LB&I, EO, or Fed State Local/ET team coordinator) q. Keeping ﬁles of all IDR copies and following up on time r. Maintaining the IDR log (see IRM
- Exhibit

, IDR Log) s. Participating in issue development and resolution t. Putting together all team members’ workpapers into one overall Large Case ﬁle u. Drafting the closing letter(s) for the manager’s approval As the exam progresses, the coordinator: a. Plans the examination including the analysis of the internal controls b. Assigns examination responsibilities to Large Case Team members c. Regularly reports the issues and examination progress to the manager d. Meet with the taxpayer to discuss issues and the progress of the exami- nation

of Actions (

) The coordinator documents signiﬁcant Large Case management activity, may change the approved Large Case audit plan. Examples of signiﬁcant modiﬁcations are: a. Expanding the examination scope that will require a signiﬁcant increase in planned time b. Contracting the examination with a signiﬁcant reduction in staff time c. Redeploying employees d. Changing emphasis in exam areas regardless if the overall planned is signiﬁcantly changed e. Adding any other areas not previously identiﬁed Large Case (
) The planning process is one of the most important case activities. (
) Involve the taxpayer in the planning process. (
) The manager actively helps the coordinator in this process. (
) The manager should consider other matters such as the prevailing economic factors. (
) The manager and coordinator evaluate the need for support when they plan the examination. (

) If the taxpayer is engaged in an issue identiﬁed for specialization and coordi- nation (such as abusive tax avoidance transaction (ATAT) issues), the Large Case team coordinator contacts the designated specialist for advice and help. (

) The manager and coordinator must become familiar with the taxpayer’s business operations. They review and analyze the following to determine staffing requirements, specialists needed, and the general approach to the amination: a. Plan returns b. Plan sponsor’s returns c. Other planning sources (see IRM
, Other Planning Sources) (

) Upon completion of the preliminary review, the coordinator summarizes: a. Issues which will be priority in the examination Note: The coordinator must consider the internal controls analysis when selecting the examination issues. b. Overall exam scope and approach c. Specialists and non-specialists members needed d. Estimated completion date (

) The coordinator notiﬁes all specialists involved in the examination and advises them of: a. The date, time, and place of any scheduled meeting(s) b. The scheduled starting date of the examination c. The description of data available for review Plans Large Case Examinations
page

4.71 Employee Plans Examination of Returns
The manager and coordinator must review related returns to determine:

Scope and complexity of examination areas selected Location and availability of records Extent of computer assisted examination techniques Coordination with LB&I, EO, or Fed State Local/ET Experience of the coordinator and team members Travel time (on
site vs. support) Taxpayer’s staffing and cooperation

-Exhibit
, EPTA Financial Interest Disclosure. Each team member must complete and sign a separate form. See Policy Statement
and Policy Statement

) The manager: a. Reviews each Financial Interest Disclosure form b. Determines whether a potential conﬂict of interest may exist c. Signs each form (
) If a potential conﬂict of interest may exist: a. The manager and the applicable team member complete Form
Example: A potential conﬂict of interest may exist if the team member owns publicly traded securities of the taxpayer valued at more than $
See the instructions to Form
b. If the manager determines that a ﬁnancial interest (as deﬁned in the Standards of Ethical Conduct for Employees of the Executive Branch, C.F.R. part

, subpart D) does not exist, the team member will remain on the team. Note: A key factor in determining this is whether the team member’s on the case will cause others to question his/her impartiality and independence. c. If the manager determines that a ﬁnancial interest may exist, he/she won’t permit the member to work on the case. d. The manager may seek legal advice from the Ethics and General Gov- ernment Law Branch of General Legal Services if they need help determining this and will remove the member from the case until he/she determines that there’s no ﬁnancial conﬂict of interest. (
) The manager certiﬁes to their area manager that there is no conﬂict of interest with respect to their personal or ﬁnancial interest using the Large Case Financial Interest Disclosure Form. See IRM
-Exhibit
for an example of the Large Case Financial Interest Disclosure Form). (
) If a potential conﬂict exists, the manager follows the disclosure procedures completes the certiﬁcation form discussed in the handbook for the Rules of Conduct. (
) Save the Financial Interest Disclosure form in the RCCMS Office Documents folder using the RCCMS Naming Convention. the Large (

) This section describes the following elements of the Large Case examination: a. Notice of examination b. Opening conference c. Internal controls d. Large Case engagement agreement e. Large Case audit plan f. Large Case workpapers Examination (
) The coordinator signs the “Notice of Examination Letter” and mails it to the taxpayer early in the examination process, either before or with the initial (
) Use Letter
, Initial Exam Appointment Letter, when the team identiﬁes speciﬁc plans under examination. Plans Large Case Examinations
page (

The manager and the applicable team member complete Form 6782.
If the manager determines that a ﬁnancial interest may exist, he/she won’t permit the member to work on the case. The manager may seek legal advice from the Ethics and General Gov
ernment Law Branch of General Legal Services if they need help determining this and will remove the member from the case until he/she determines that there’s no ﬁnancial conﬂict of interest.
The coordinator signs the “Notice of Examination Letter” and mails it to the taxpayer early in the examination process, either before or with the initial IDRs.
Employee Plans Examination of Returns

) The opening conference is a face-to-face meeting with the taxpayer’s autho- rized employees. Its purpose is to: a. Discuss the case selection process b. Verify the taxpayer’s size, dispersion, and all related entities c. Conﬁrm the availability of the books and records d. Discuss the accounting system and compliance with Rev. Proc.
, IRB

e. Arrange for the availability of information and documents at the start of the examination f. Arrange for ﬂow of communications from the Large Case manager and the Large Case team coordinator to the taxpayer and vice versa g. Establish agreements as to accommodations for the team, including items as secure office space, locked ﬁle cabinets, parking arrangements, and security badges h. Establish agreement that the coordinator will raise, discuss, and resolve issues as the examination progresses i. Establish agreement that the taxpayer will prepare its protest to identiﬁed unagreed issues during the examination j. Establish agreement on security of IRS and taxpayer documents kept on the taxpayer’s premises during the examination k. Establish agreement for response time frames of IDRs, Notices of Proposed Adjustments/Issues (NOPAs), etc. Note: IDR response dates should be mutually agreed upon and comply with general program examination requirements. l. Discuss the exam scope and depth m. Plan a meeting with the taxpayer and appropriate staff to discuss the payer’s internal controls, processes and procedures for plan operations n. Provide an estimated completion date for the examination (

) The coordinator gets a written authorization at the opening conference or planning stage that lists the names and titles of those individuals who have authority to provide information and enter into agreements. This helps avoid potential miscommunication or inadvertent disclosure. a. A taxpayer-authorized official must sign the written authorization. b. If the authorization identiﬁes an individual other than an employee(s) acting within the scope of their employment, then this form should be similar to Form
, and all of its restrictions. c. Because the Large Case authorization form’s use is limited, you may need to obtain a properly completed Form

) The manager should ensure that: a. Taxpayer employees designated to give team members information should be those who are best qualiﬁed to give complete ﬁrst-hand infor- mation. b. ) After concluding the opening conference, the coordinator prepares written minutes of the meeting which summarize pertinent information developed and agreements made.

(4) After concluding the opening conference, the coordinator prepares written minutes of the meeting which summarize pertinent information developed and
) Analyzing the taxpayer’s internal controls is an important part of a Large examination. (
) Large Case examiners must examine the internal controls of the plan sponsor, take appropriate actions and record the results of their actions and analysis the case ﬁle. (

) Internal controls are a system of procedures the taxpayer and the plan admin- istrator use to: a. Ensure and promote the information’s reliability and accuracy to adminis- ter the plan and calculate beneﬁts per the written plan document. b. Ensure that the plan operationally complies with plan provisions and Internal Revenue Code (Code). c. Safeguard plan participant beneﬁts and the trust assets from fraud, and abuse. (
) These systems and processes support plan operations and include: a. The process for keeping plans qualiﬁed in form under IRC

(a) and other applicable Code sections b. Day-to-day plan operations (both qualiﬁed and non-qualiﬁed plans) c. Payroll systems used to capture compensation data for beneﬁt and testing purposes (such as allocations) d. Human Resources and Beneﬁts Department actions (such as determina- tion of eligibility) e. Process for determining pension expenses and deductions f. Trust investment strategies g. Distribution responsibilities h. End of year testing responsibilities (

) In the early stages of the Large Case examination, the coordinator analyzes internal controls to determine their level within the various systems and processes the taxpayer uses to administer their plan(s) and capture data. (

) The objectives of the internal controls analysis is to: a. Understand the systems the taxpayer uses to administer their qualiﬁed retirement plan processes b. Understand how these systems work independently and how they interact with each other c. Verify the level of data accuracy input into the various systems d. Help develop the audit plan (

) An effective analysis of internal controls will help the Large Case Team: a. Identify the plan sponsor’s internal controls of their systems and processes vulnerabilities b. Develop an audit plan that includes potential areas of non-compliance c. Get a level of conﬁdence in how well the internal controls are working operation d. Revise the preliminary review and formulate an audit plan for the focused examination e. Expand or limit the scope of the examination (
) Suggested methods and types of analysis include: Large Case Examinations

The coordinator completes the Large Case engagement agreement after the opening conference and in the early stages of the examination.
In communicating with the taxpayer, the manager should be sure that:
Employee Plans Large Case Examinations 4.71.16 page

a. The written authorization agreement speciﬁes the authorized individuals in the taxpayer’s organization who will furnish information, discuss tax matters, negotiate adjustments and approve adjustments to tax returns with the team. b. Taxpayer employees designated to furnish information to team members are the best-qualiﬁed persons to give complete ﬁrst-hand information. This may include people responsible for preparing the examination documents. Audit Plan (

) The purpose of the Large Case audit plan is to outline the exam’s scope, depth and special techniques and inform team members of their speciﬁc as- signments. Team members will: a. Use their time in the best way. b. Know their role in the examination, how to proceed and, if necessary, information they should develop for other team members. (
) Use Form
(Large Case), or similar computer generated form. See IRM
- Exhibit
, Sample EPTA Audit Plan for an example. (
) Use standardized workpapers and reports and create a single ﬁle or report. (
) State procedures for labeling and controlling electronic data. (
) Use the same workpaper standards as for general examinations program ex- aminations. See IRM
, Workpapers. Indexing (
) Consistently index workpapers using the Employee Plans Examination Standard Audit Index Number (E-SAIN) system. See IRM
- Exhibit
ESAIN Number System for a list of ESAIN numbers with descriptions. (
) You can also use the E-SAIN system to: a. Assign work in the audit plan b. Develop standard examination procedures and workpapers (commonly done on Form
-B). See IRM
- Exhibit
, Form
-B for example. c. Identify the subject and organize IDRs d. Link exhibits to the workpapers (
) The manager can approve another method of indexing workpapers in appropri- ate circumstances; however, all team members assigned to the case must the same system. Document Process (
) The IDR process gives the team a structured process to use when gathering information during an examination. (

) During the opening conference, the manager and coordinator discuss the process for managing IDRs and meet with the taxpayer to determine the IDR response times. Include the resulting agreement in the opening conference minutes and the Large Case engagement agreement. (
) The coordinator keeps an IDR log to monitor IDR status and follow up when an IDR response is delinquent. See IRM
- Exhibit
, IDR Log for an example. Plans Large Case Examinations

) The coordinator contacts the taxpayer to discuss problems and reasons for delay. If necessary, involve the manager. Document these discussions for future tracking. (

) Subsequent discussions include: a. Evaluating other ways or sources to get the requested or needed infor- mation b. If necessary, preparing and issuing a follow-up IDR to the delinquent IDR. ) If the taxpayer doesn’t respond to requests for information, consider serving summons when you need to pursue an issue and don’t have sufficient facts develop or resolve the issue. The coordinator consults with Area Counsel guidance to prepare and issue the summons.
